listitem.para: The four icons in the left upper corner represent the vector layers and they are the starting point of the GIS app.
In the top right corner you get an overview of the layers:

If you are online you will see Google Streets and Google Hybrid which can be used as background maps and layers. Switch between the two of them by checking the checkbox. The default base map is OpenStreetMap. To get a nice background map, select the OSM Light. By clearing a box you can hide the corresponding background completely.
If you want to see the background, but with reduced opacity, you can set the visibility to something lower than 100 % in the numberbox to the right.

The final four layers are the vector layers which you use for thematic mapping (explained in the next section). The panels below hold the map legends when you create a thematic map. A legend explains the link between values and colors on your map.
Zoom to content automatically adjusts the zoom level and map center position to put the data on your map in focus.
To get information for an event you can simply click on it. This opens a pop-up window which displays all available information for that event.
The current longitude and latitude position of the mouse cursor is displayed in the bottom right corner of the map.

section.title: Create a new thematic map
section.para: You use four vector layers to create a thematic map. The workflow for creating a new thematic map is:

listitem.para: In the Apps menu, click GIS.
The DHIS 2 GIS window opens.
In the top menu, click a layer you want to add to the map.
Event layer
Facility layer
Boundary layer
Thematic layer 1 - 4
Click Edit layer and select the parameters you need..
Click Update.

section.title: Manage event layer
section.para: The purpose of the event layer is to display the geographical location of events registered in the DHIS 2 tracker. This layer lets you drill down from the aggregated data displayed in the thematic layers to the underlying individual events or cases.

section.title: Create or modify event layer
section.para: To create or modify the event layer:

listitem.para: In the top menu, click the event layer icon.
Click Edit layer.
Select a program and then select a program stage.
If there is only one stage available for the selected program, the stage is automatically selected. A list of data elements and attributes will appear in the Available data items panel.
Select any data element or attribute from this list as part of your query.

To select you can either double-click a data element or (multi) select and use the single-arrow downward button. The double-arrow button will select all data elements in the list. All selected data elements will get their own row in the Selected data items.
You can use an element multiple times in your query by clicking Duplicate.

For data elements of type text you will get two choices: Contains implies that the query will match all values which contains your search value, and Is exact implies that only values which is completely identical to your search query will be returned.
For data elements of type option set, you can select any of the options from the drop down box by using the down-wards arrow or by start typing directly in the box to filter for options.
In the Periods section, select the time span for when the events took place. You can select either a fixed period or a relative period.
Fixed period: In the Period field, select Start/end dates and fill in a start date and an end date.
Relative period: In the Period field, select one of the relative periods, for example This month or Last year.
In the Organisation units section, select the organisation units you want to include in the query.
In the Options section, select if you want group nearby events and change style of the cluster points.
Click Update.

section.para: The layer menu also offers to put labels on the map
to close the layer, which completely resets the layer content.

section.title: Turn off cluster
section.para: By default events are clustered in a map. You can turn off this function to display all events seperatly.

listitem.para: Click Event layer > Edit layer.
Click Options.
Clear Group nearby events checkbox.
Click Update.

section.title: Modify the style of cluster points

listitem.para: In the top menu, click the event layer icon.
Click Edit layer.
In the Options section, change the Point color and Point radius.
Click Update.

section.title: Modify information in event pop-up windows
section.para: For events in a cluster map, you can modify the information displayed in the event pop-up window.

listitem.para: On the home page, click Apps > Programs / Attributes.
Click Program.
Click the program you want to modify and select View program stages.
Click the program stage name and select Edit.
Scroll down to the Selected data elements section.
For every data element you want to display in the pop-up window, select corresponding Display in reports.
Click Update.

section.title: Manage facility layer
section.para: The facility layer displays icons that represent facilities based on the facility type. Polygons will not show up on the map, so make sure to select an organisation unit level that has facilities.

Click an icon on the map to open the context menu with two options. "Show information sheet" provides you with data for several data elements for this organisation unit. The data element group and period type are "system settings" called "Infrastructural data elements" and "Infrastructural period type".

section.title: Create or modify facility layer
section.para: To create or modify the facilty layer:

listitem.para: In the top menu, click the facility layer icon.
Click Edit layer.
In the Organisation unit group icons section, select a Group set.
In the Organisation units section, select one or several organisation units.
In the Options section, select if you want to show lables and if so, how they look.
In the Options section, select if you want to display a circule with a certain radius around each facility.
Click Update.

section.title: Change location of an organisation unit
section.para: The second option in the context menu is "Relocate" and lets you graphically move the organisation unit to a different location. The new coordinate will be stored permanently. Browser cache must be deleted to see the change if you reload the page.

section.title: Manage boundary layer
section.para: The purpose of the boundary layer is to display the boundaries and coordinates in the system. No data will be shown. This layer is useful if you are offline and thus have no background map.

When there are visible organisation units on the map, you can easily navigate up and down in the hierarchy without using the level/parent user interface. By clicking one of the organisation units a context menu will open, then select "drill down" or "float up". The drill down option will be disabled if you are already on the lowest level or if there are no coordinates available on the level below. Vice versa goes for floating up.
The layer menu also offers to put on labels and to locate an organisation unit in the map.
The final option in the layer menu is "Close". This completely resets the layer content, the edit layer form and the legend panel.

section.title: Create or modify boundary layer
section.para: To create or modify the boundary layer:

listitem.para: In the top menu, click the boundary layer icon.
Click Edit layer.
In the Organisation units section, select one or several organisation units.
You can select the organisation units you want to show on the map by selecting a level and a parent. That means "show all organisations units at this level that are children of this parent".
In the Options section, select if you want to show lables and if so, how they look.
Click Update.

section.title: Manage thematic layer 1- 4
section.para: The four thematic layer panels let you use your data for thematic mapping. All you need to do is selecting your desired combination of indicator/dataelement, period and map combination. Then the organisation unit level and parent to define the boundaries. If your database has coordinates and aggregated data values for these organisation units they will appear on the map.

note.para: The DHIS 2 data mart must be run in order to have aggregated values available.

section.para: Low radius and high radius only have effect on points (facilities) and decides the circle radius for points with the lowest and highest value.

section.title: Create or modify a thematic layer
section.para: To create or modify a thematic layer:

listitem.para: In the top menu, click the icon of thematic layer you want to create or modify.
Click Edit layer.
In the Data and periods section, select
In the Organisation units section, select one or several organisation units.
In the Legend seciton, select Automatic or Predefined legend type.

Automatic legend types means that the application will create a legend set for you based on your what method, number of classes, low color and high color you select. Method alludes to the size of the legend classes.
Set to Equal intervals they will be “highest map value – lowest map value / number of classes”.
Set to Equal counts the legend creator will try to distribute the organisation units eveenly.
The legend appears as an even gradation from the start color to the end color.
For information about Predefined legend sets, see .
In the Options section, select if you want to show lables and if so, how they look.
Click Update.
Click x to close the window.

section.title: Filter values in a thematic layer
section.para: Thematic layer 1-4 menu have a "Filter" option in addition to the boundary layer menu options. It lets you apply value filters to the organisation units on the map. The filter is removed when you close the filter window.
To filter values in a thematic layer:

listitem.para: In the top menu, click the icon of thematic layer you want to create or modify.
Click Filter....
Modify the Greater than and And/or lower than values.
Click Update.
Click x to close the window.

section.title: Manage map favorites
section.para: Saving your maps as favorites makes it easy to restore them later. It also gives you the opportunity to share it with other users as an interpretation or put it on the dashboard. You can also save an even layer as a favorite.

section.title: Save a map as favorite
section.para: When you have created a map it is convenient to save it as a favorite:

listitem.para: Click Favorites.
The Manage favorites dialog box opens.
Click Add new.
The Create new favorite dialog box opens.
In the text field, type the name you want to give your pivot table.
Click Create.
Your favorite is added to the list.
Click Favorites.
The Manage favorites dialog box opens.
Find the favorite you want to open. You can either use Prev and Next or the search field to find a saved favorite. The list is filtered on every character that you enter.
Click the name.
The selected favorite opens.

section.title: Overwrite a favorite
section.para: To save the current map to an existing favorite (overwrite):

listitem.para: Click Favorites.
The Manage favorites dialog box opens.
Find the favorite you want to overrite.
You can either use Prev and Next or the search field to find a saved favorite.
Click the green overwrite icon next to the favorite's name.
Click OK to confirm that you want to overwrite the favorite.
Click x to close the window.

section.title: Rename a favorite
section.para: To edit the name of a favorite:

listitem.para: Click Favorites.
The Manage favorites dialog box opens.
Find the favorite you want to overrite.
You can either use Prev and Next or the search field to find a saved favorite.
Click the gray overwrite icon next to the favorite's name.
The Rename favorite dialog box favorite opens.
Type the new name and click Update.
Click x to close the window.

section.title: Delete a favorite
section.para: To delete a favorite:

listitem.para: Click Favorites.
The Manage favorites dialog box opens.
Find the favorite you want to delete.
You can either use Prev and Next or the search field to find a saved favorite.
Click the red delete next to the favorite's name.
Click OK to confirm that you want to delete the favorite.
Click x to close the window.

section.title: Share an interpretation of a favorite/map interpretation
section.para: For certain analysis-related resources in DHIS 2, you can share a data interpretation. An interpretation is a link to the relevant resource together with a text expressing some insight about the data.
To create an interpretation of a map and share it with all users of the system:

listitem.para: Open or create a favorite map.
Click Share > Write interpretation.
The Write interpretation dialog box opens.
In the text field, type a comment, question or interpretation.
Click Share.
The dialog box closes automatically. You can see the interpretation on the Dashboard.

section.title: Manage map legend sets
section.para: You can create your own legend sets to ensure meaningful maps.

note.para: Continuous legends are supposed to end and start on the same value, for example 0-50 and 50-80. The GIS app automatically take care of this. Do not try to do this yourself by setting legends to for example 0-50 and 51-80. This will cause a usually unwanted gap in your legend set.

listitem.para: Click Legends.
The Legend sets dialog box opens.
Click Add new.
In the Legend set name field, type the name you want to give the legend set.
Create the legends you want to have in your legend set:
In the Legend name field, type the legend name.
Select Start/end value.
Select a Symbolizer.
Click Add legend.
The legend is added to Current legends.
Repeat until you have created all the legends you need.
Click Create.

note.para: If your legend set has overlapping legends (for example 0-50 and 40-80) you will not be allowed to proceed. If your legend set has a gap between the legends (for example 0-50 and 60-80) you will get a warning, but are allowed to proceed.

listitem.para: Click Legends.
The Legend sets dialog box opens.
Click the edit icon next to the legend set you want to modify.
In the Current legends list, click the edit icon next to the legend you want to modify.
The Edit legend dialog box opens.
Modify the parameters and click Update.
In the Legend sets dialog box, click Update.
Click Legends.
The Legend sets dialog box opens.
Click the delete icon next to the legend set you want to delete.

section.title: Assign a legend set to indicator or data element
section.para: You can assign a legend set to an indicator or a data element in the Indicator/Data element module. This legend set will then be automatically selected when such an indicator/data element is selected in the GIS.

listitem.para: Take a screenshot of the map with the tool of your choice.
Save the screenshot in desired format.

section.title: Embed map in external web page
section.para: Certain analysis-related resources in DHIS 2, like pivot tables, charts and maps, can be embedded in any web page by using a plugin. You will find more information about the plugins in the Web API chapter in the DHIS2 Developer Manual.
To generate a HTML fragment that you can use to display the map in an external web page:

listitem.para: Click Share > Embed in web page.
The Embed in web page window opens.
Click Select to highlight the HTML fragment.
Click x to close the window.

section.title: Measure distance and area in map
section.para: To measure distance and area in a map:

listitem.para: In the upper left part of the map, put the curser on the Measure distances and areas icon anc click Create new measurement.
Add points to the map.
Click Finish measurement.

section.title: Visualize map as a pivot table or chart
section.para: When you have made a map you can switch between pivot table, chart and map visualization of your data. The function is inactive if the data the map is based on cannot render as a chart or table.

listitem.para: Click Chart > Open this map as chart.
Your current map opens as a chart.
Click Chart > Open this map as table.
Your current map opens as a pivot table.
